Adult male.description: Eurasian Wigeons can be separated from American Wigeons by their head and forehead color; Eurasians have a chestnut head and a buffy forehead and American Wigeons have a grayish brown head and a white crown.

Female.description: Female Eurasian Wigeons have a rustier head than female American Wigeons. Best told by the silver (not white) underwings on Eurasian Wigeons in flight.

Breeding male (American).description: Green-winged Teals are smaller than American Wigeons with a chestnut face and neck, and a vertical white bar on its side that wigeons lack.

Female/nonbreeding male.description: Female Green-winged Teals are smaller than American Wigeons with a larger bill. They also have a creamy streak near the rear that wigeons lack.

Breeding male.description: Breeding male Gadwalls lack the male American Wigeon's white forehead and have darker body plumage and bill than female American Wigeons.

Female.description: Female Gadwalls can be separated from female American Wigeons by their longer orange bill.
